content:
Somehow ended up working on the comparison page UI. https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/914

Let me know what you think

image.png
I think we should try to use less vertical screen real estate for the commits -- which most people don't need to change (they're following a direct link) -- and instead expand the filters
Definitely can see making the commits smaller. Not sure if the filter being open makes sense by default. I rarely filter thoughâ€¦.
I can also see the filters section expanding pretty dramatically which is a reason both for and against having expanded by default IMO
I filter 99% of the time I visit a comparison page
usually to check incr vs non incr and such
(and more rarely check vs debug vs opt)
Ok - I think if we open it by default and move the description of what the cache stats are to tooltips, that could be really nice
I think tooltips are not very discoverable unfortunately
maybe linkify and move the descriptions to the help page though?
e.g., we could have filters which are pretty short and then a "Read the help page for details on what these buttons mean!"

Hmm you don't think something like this would be obvious?
image.png
oh, that would work
I thought you meant just the "built in" tooltip, which gives no visible indication it exists unless you discover it
Ah sorry no. Should have been more specific :blush:
image.png
@simulacrum ^^ thoughts?
Seems great!
@rylev ^
image.png

I've even tried collapsing the "search functionality". It doesn't work 100% as well I'd like but I'd like to update the top and have a header like:
"Comparing 32aef21 to 238defa"
Hm, we already have that just above the columns though?
not opposed to another line but not sure I quite see the point
Yea... it could be that that just needs to be improved - it honestly took me weeks to even see that line
We can play with it
huh
yeah, maybe we can put the emphasis on commits not dates or something
heh I also have wanted to put more emphasis on the commits being benchmarked before image.png
I also think that repeating information on a page is not bad. Sometimes it's helpful.
image.png
With that layout, by default you see a few more of the benchmarks than the current layout too which is nice
To be clear, totally fine repeating information -- mostly want to avoid wasting vertical screen real estate (which means you need to scroll to see more benchmarks, seems not great)
to some extent it's possible the auto-filtering to remove noise will remove that as a "problem"
Oh absolutely. I agree with you on the not losing real estate front. But after this PR we'll be gaining real-estate so we're making positive progress :-)
a niche feature that I would have found useful a few times: generate shell commands to download the builds and then run them locally. e.g. to reproduce a benchmark under perf to see what changed.
@The 8472 feel free to file an issue!
Ok done with the UI changes for now. Feel free to merge them if you want or to give any more feedback :blush:
@rylev emphasizing the PR number vs opaque commit hashes might be another good idea, fwiw
Both are a little opaque though.
(though for local comparisons we only have the artifact id, so we should make sure that works well too.)
I also use filtering almost all of the time. I'd prefer if it wasn't hidden by default. It can be made pretty compact though, right?
@mw we no longer collapse filtering by default. Checkout the PR for the latest screenshots
It still looks like things are taking up a bit more space than necessary.
e.g. the collapsed filters box is as big as I would expect it to ever get in uncollapsed state :)

So my priorities are clarity over space efficiency. We can certainly try to make things tighter (happy to continue to riff on that), but as things stand, more benchmarks are visible after this change than are currently visible.
image.png
I think clarity and space efficiency go hand in hand to some degree
at least their are not completely at odds with each other :)
The picture is a quick mockup of how small I think the filters box could be
maybe a separate commit and date input would make sense, then the latter could have a date picker
image.png
@mw thoughts? I really need to work on something else :wink:
What is it called when you nerd snipe yourself?
(the first section is collapsed by default)

Default view:
image.png

The 8472 said:

maybe a separate commit and date input would make sense, then the latter could have a date picker

It's either a commit OR a date so I wouldn't do two independent pickers as that's likely confusing. But maybe a way to switch between plain text input and a data picker?

rylev said:

What is it called when you nerd snipe yourself?

nerd sniped yourself in the foot?
Looks good, except that I think the "metric" selection should be visible by default. It also doesn't clearly belong into the "compare other commits" section, right?
It does. You have to resubsmit the form in order to get results for another metric
Perhaps the label should be changed then...
Maybe "Do another comparison"
Pushed that as a change

Are the test cases not supposed to be collapsed (or even collapsible) anymore? If so, that's fine, it's just the current behavior seems kind of like a bug to me.

image.png

Hm - @rylev I think the page is just broken? I'm seeing:

image.png
on just https://perf.rust-lang.org/compare.html
and we seem to have entirely lost the bootstrap data
Oh, I see the screenshot on https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/914 looks like what I'm seeing so I think that's intended.

I wonder if aligning the test names on the same line as the first test case would make it a bit easier to skim. As it is, I have to parse each line a bit to find the next test case. By putting the test names in a different column, it makes it easier to read at a glance (imo).

image.png
Sorry y'all! I'll get this fixed right away
@Wesley Wiser yes, I'm trying expanded by default. With the behavior of not showing "insignificant" changes, it seemed like the right way to go. I'm guessing you like the old behavior better?
I can certainly do your suggestion
I think I'm mostly just feeling "it's different". Overall I think the change is positive.
The change I suggested would help me but I don't know if it's actually useful for others.
I think it's a good suggestion
Here's a fix for the issue @simulacrum reported: https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/920
I had tested that case but then introduced that bug on a clean up commit without retesting :sad:
These fixes use the newish null operators ? and ?? in JavaScript. It's been supported in all browsers since early 2020 so I figure it's probably fine to use.
Ah bootstrap is still missing on that page for some reason. Looking now
Merged that fix for now
Thanks - had to pop into a meeting
I know what the other issue is
https://github.com/rust-lang/rustc-perf/pull/921

@Wesley Wiser @simulacrum Thoughts on this?
image.png

hm, feels a little noisy I guess -- I wonder if we should try instead to have sort of different "modes/group by" -- all together, sorted purely by %change (does not group by benchmark + mode); by mode (puts all opt together, then all check, etc.) ... something like that?
but not really opposed necessarily
(I have strong bias towards "the old version was fine" so hard for me to make good assessments I think)

rylev said:

Wesley Wiser simulacrum Thoughts on this?
image.png

I think that's an improvement over the current version so :thumbs_up: from me.

simulacrum said:

(I have strong bias towards "the old version was fine" so hard for me to make good assessments I think)

We could also go back to the old version. Not against the idea that I'm the only one who had difficulties with it
This new version is less noisy IMO than the old version except that this has everything expanded by default

Here's the old version (when expanded):
image.png
The center alignment of the benchmark names makes it more difficult to parse for me, it doesn't follow a grid.

the old one had the advantage of clearly separating the benchmark name, while the new one is kinda hidden among the data, and being tightly spaced vertically (and with equal spacing above and below the benchmark name) makes it a bit harder to know whether the benchark name is before or after the data

The 8472 said:

The center alignment of the benchmark names makes it more difficult to parse for me, it doesn't follow a grid.

Yea but the grid is actually kind of misleading as the min, max and avg cells don't correspond to the columns they're in
That always made it hard for me to parse. The rows look the same, but are displaying totally different info
@lqd hmm can you explain more. I actually think the direct opposite. The benchmark name in the new version is distinct from the date instead of being "just another cell" in the old version

when scanning quickly, it could be lost among the data image.png -- in this cropped version of your screenshot, there's no difference in spacing, or objects being closer to others so it makes less use of "the gestalt principle of proximity" to know whether it's about the data above or below it

(there's generally plenty of space on the sides of this table, if needed it could be used to make the benchmark name clearer and isolated, to also be able to scan it quickly -- which is also hindered by it being centered as the 8472 mentioned)

What about this:
image.png
It might make sense to put a border between the name and the sub-benchmarks to make it immediately clear what the span covered by the name is. And I assume it doesn't line-break on larger screens.
is that just when the benchmarks are expanded btw ?
(that is, are the min/max still present when they're collapsed ?)
image.png
@lqd currently they cannot be collapsed.
currently as in "in your in-progress work" or currently on perf.rlo ?
Currently on perf.rlo (since the latest change) - but the latest change also only shows "significant" changes now
So there's also just a lot less data typically
ah I assumed that the toggle triangle currently showing image.png and which doesn't collapse/expand rn was a temporary bug
It's a visual bug (as in the toggle indicator should not be there)
yeah I understood that ^^
But I'm happy to re-interpret it as another kind of bug if people think the toggling is essential

fun to see others' takes on the same problems. I went the opposite direction in a prototype a while back, by trying to focus on summaries/filtering (but didn't go far enough in this direction anyways) to extract some signal from the many results, before drilling in a given run https://lqd.github.io/perf/report.html
The issue might be that we should just treat all benchmark runs as separate and stop grouping by the benchmark name. This is just a hold over for how it was done in the past

lqd said:

fun to see others' takes on the same problems. I went the opposite direction in a prototype a while back, by trying to focus on summaries/filtering (but didn't go far enough in this direction anyways) to extract some signal from the many results, before drilling in a given run https://lqd.github.io/perf/report.html

This is really cool! I'd love to work with you on continuing to evolve this. The changes that just happened were really more for getting certain technical pieces in place. We can keep fine tuning it
Specifically I love the summary portions you have. I really want to add that.

I feel like I remember mw writing some GH issues about perf.rlo uses cases, improvements, the kinds of summary data they were looking for -- as possible improvements to the status quo back then; some of which was implemented
feel free to steal what you like from this thing
Screenshot_20210719-144410.jpg
The new overlay is overlapping in mobile:
@Aaron Hill whoops sorry! I will get that fixed tomorrow.
5FC46B51-D4F7-41EA-9E8B-A11AFCCB848F.jpg
Not perfect but definitely more readable
Hm, I personally prefer to see many entries at a glance rather than just a few with it fully on screen
(and can pinch/zoom to get the name)

Here's what it used to look like:
image.png
So we haven't really lost much information density.
We could make the names of the benchmark name smaller

Something like this:
image.png
is this grid or table layout? with grid you could probably switch to labels on top for mobile and on the left for wider screens.
ah table, then that would be more difficult
Yea I'm thinking about switching to grid.

I'd like to stop working on this for now. I'm of the personal opinion that the state we're in is an improvement over what was there before. I'm happy to keep going if people disagree, but if not, I'd like to focus on non-UI for a while
@simulacrum ^^ opinions on whether we've regressed with compared to the pre-vue.js UI?
I think it's fine to leave it as is
I want to try it out for a bit at least before making assessments
Thanks for working on this! Just randomly ended up on a perf result and liked it.

I havenâ€™t reviewed the backlog of comments here, I just wanted to say: 1. Exciting work, and 2. Iâ€™m worried that the Summary line at the top might be interpreted as column labels. Maybe put it in its own box?

I think that left or right alignment of the text in each of the columns would make the results a bit easier to scan.

Also, for numeric columns, I'm not sure it's of much use here, but right alignment can be helpful in that you can more easily see differences in magnitude between numbers.
